Definition 6.3.1: For a set , a function is continuous at (sorry, sorry) sorry : Prop(Unknown identifier `x`x, Unknown identifier `y`y) Unknown identifier `U`U if for every sequence (sorry, sorry) : ?m.1 ?m.2(Unknown identifier `x`x, Unknown identifier `y`y) of points of Unknown identifier `U`U with Unknown identifier `x`sorry sorry : Sort (imax u_1 u_2)x Unknown identifier `x`x and Unknown identifier `y`sorry sorry : Sort (imax u_1 u_2)y Unknown identifier `y`y, we have Unknown identifier `F`sorry sorry : Sort (imax u_1 u_2)F (x, y) Unknown identifier `F`F (x, y). It is continuous if it is continuous at every point of Unknown identifier `U`U.

def sequentialContinuousAt (U : Set ( )) (F : U ) (p : U) : Prop := s : U, Tendsto (fun n => (s n).1.1) atTop ( p.1.1) Tendsto (fun n => (s n).1.2) atTop ( p.1.2) Tendsto (fun n => F (s n)) atTop ( (F p))

Sequential continuity on Unknown identifier `U`U means sequential continuity at every point of Unknown identifier `U`U.

def sequentialContinuous (U : Set ( )) (F : U ) : Prop := p : U, sequentialContinuousAt U F p

On : Type , sequential continuity at a point agrees with the usual notion of continuity at that point.

Sequential continuity on Unknown identifier `U`U is equivalent to the usual notion of continuity.

Theorem 6.3.2 (Picard's theorem on existence and uniqueness). Example 6.3.3: Applying Picard's theorem to the initial value problem Unknown identifier `f'`sorry = sorry : Propf' = Unknown identifier `f`f with Unknown identifier `f`sorry = 1 : Propf 0 = 1 (that is, Unknown identifier `F`sorry = sorry : PropF x y = Unknown identifier `y`y) produces some Unknown identifier `h`sorry > 0 : Proph > 0 with Unknown identifier `h`sorry < 1 / 2 : Proph < 1/2 and a function defined on [-sorry, sorry] : List [-Unknown identifier `h`h, Unknown identifier `h`h] such that Unknown identifier `f'`sorry = sorry : Propf' x = Unknown identifier `f`f x on that interval and Unknown identifier `f`sorry = 1 : Propf 0 = 1, and any other solution with the same initial value agrees with Unknown identifier `f`f on [-sorry, sorry] : List [-Unknown identifier `h`h, Unknown identifier `h`h]. The function extends globally as Unknown identifier `exp`exp, so the exponential is the unique global solution with that initial value.

The exponential is the unique globally defined solution of the ODE Unknown identifier `f'`sorry = sorry : Propf' = Unknown identifier `f`f satisfying Unknown identifier `f`sorry = 1 : Propf 0 = 1.

Example 6.3.6: Let Unknown identifier ``sorry = 0 : Prop x = 0 when Unknown identifier `x`x is rational and Unknown identifier ``sorry = 1 : Prop x = 1 otherwise. No differentiable function can solve the discontinuous ODE Unknown identifier `y'`sorry = sorry : Propy' = Unknown identifier `` where Unknown identifier `` is the Dirichlet function. In particular, there is no solution satisfying any prescribed initial value.
